metadata.description:
This data is the data of the automatic weather station (AWS, Campbell company) set up in Yigong Zangbu basin by the Southeast Tibet alpine environment comprehensive observation and research station of Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2018. The geographic coordinates are 30.1741 n, 94.9334 e, and the altitude is 2282m. The underlying surface is grassland.
The data include daily arithmetic mean data of air temperature (℃), relative humidity (%), wind speed (M / s), water vapor pressure (kPa) and air pressure (MB) and daily accumulated value of precipitation. The original data is an average value recorded in 10 minutes. The temperature and humidity are measured by hmp155a temperature and humidity probe. The rainfall instrument is tb4, the atmospheric pressure sensor is ptb210, and the wind speed sensor is 05103. These probes are 2 m above the ground. Data quality: the quality of the original data is better, less missing. The data station is a meteorological station in the lower altitude of the Qinghai Tibet Plateau, which will be updated from time to time in the future. It can be used by researchers studying climate, hydrology, glaciers, etc.
metadata.instructions:
File name: Yigong basic meteorological data (2018-2019)
The file type is excel
It can be opened in office and WPS

background: In mountainous areas, different altitudes exhibit distinct vertical zonation due to variations in water (precipitation) and heat (temperature) components. The southeastern Tibet Sejila Mountain has a pronounced mountain vertical zonation feature: from the foot of the mountain to the summit, it includes broadleaf forest, mixed coniferous and broadleaf forest, coniferous forest, shrubs, and moss. The vegetation types in Sejila Mountain are rich, and the longevity of trees is notable (Lu et al., 2015). The tree line at 4390 m is one of the highest forest lines in the world, making it a hotspot for tree-ring and forest ecology research (Wang et al., 2014; Liang et al., 2016; Shen et al., 2018). Currently, there is limited research on the vertical gradients of temperature and precipitation in Sejila Mountain (Liang et al., 2011). Most studies by some scholars on the temperature and precipitation vertical gradient changes in this region and its vicinity are primarily based on the Baji Station (formerly Linzhi Station) and the nearby Bomi Station, focusing on the vertical temperature lapse rate across the entire Tibetan Plateau (Jiang Jingchao et al., 2016; Guo et al., 2016; Li et al., 2013; Wang et al., 2001, 2018; Zhang et al., 2018) and precipitation gradients (Guo et al., 2016).
research objective: Therefore, this article explores the vertical variation patterns of temperature and precipitation on the eastern and western slopes of the Sejila Mountain based on temperature and precipitation data from 11 meteorological stations. This not only deepens the understanding of the influence of slope orientation on the vertical gradient changes of temperature and precipitation in Sejila Mountain but also helps to better understand the physiological and ecological characteristics of plant and animal distribution with altitude changes in the region. Additionally, it provides reliable data support for future hydrological modeling in this watershed area.
challenges: Due to the many factors affecting the vertical temperature lapse rate and precipitation gradient, among the meteorological stations in the Sejila Mountains, except for the mountain pass station, tree line station, and ecological station located on the ridge, all other stations are situated in valley areas. Additionally, the western slope and the number of high-altitude stations are relatively few, which may affect the accuracy of the temperature lapse rate and precipitation gradient obtained in this study.
methods: The data for this study includes daily temperature and precipitation records (from April to October) from 2013 to 2018 provided by the Linzhi Meteorological Bureau of the Tibet Autonomous Region for nine stations: Bayi, Niche, Station 114, Station 113, Shankou, Ecological Station, Rulang, Bing Station, and Layue, as well as the main station of Southeast Tibet and two stations at the tree line (as shown in Figure 1 and Table 1). Based on the geographical locations of these stations, the stations in the Sejila Mountain area are divided into two natural geographical units according to their slope orientation: the western slope (southern slope) and the eastern slope (northern slope), with the Sejila Mountain Pass station belonging to both the western and eastern slopes. The vertical temperature lapse rate and precipitation gradient are estimated through regression analysis based on the elevation of the stations and their corresponding temperature or precipitation values.
dataset: The data for this study includes daily temperature and precipitation values (from April to October) from 2013 to 2018 provided by the Linzhi Meteorological Bureau of the Tibet Autonomous Region for nine stations: Bayi, Niche, Station 114, Station 113, Shankou, Ecological Station, Rulang, Bing Station, and Laye Station, as well as the main station of Southeast Tibet Station (shown in Figure 1 and Table 1) and two stations at the tree line.
findings: From 2013 to 2018, the average temperature lapse rate (λ) at 11 stations on the Selila Mountain ranged from 0.59 to 0.63°C·(100 m)^-1, with the lowest λ value in 2016 and the highest in 2014. The average λ from 2013 to 2018 was 0.60°C·(100 m)^-1. The western slope had λ values ranging from 0.69 to 0.72°C·(100 m)^-1, with 2016 also having the lowest λ and 2014 the highest. The average λ for the western slope from 2013 to 2018 was 0.71°C·(100 m)^-1. The eastern slope had λ values between 0.53 and 0.55°C·(100 m)^-1. Unlike the Selila Mountain and the western slope, the lowest λ for the eastern slope occurred in 2015, while the highest was in 2017. The average λ for the eastern slope from 2013 to 2018 was 0.55°C·(100 m)^-1. From 2013 to 2018, the average precipitation gradient on the eastern slope was 10.5 mm·(100 m)^-1, with precipitation during the monsoon period showing a trend of first increasing, then decreasing, and then increasing again with elevation; during the non-monsoon period, the trend was first decreasing and then increasing. The precipitation gradient above the southeastern Tibet station was notably significant.

Verification.Question: Is there a dataset that includes daily temperature and precipitation values from a range of meteorological stations over several years?

Disjunctive.Question: Which sensor is more commonly used for temperature and humidity measurements in meteorological data collection methods: HMP155A, PTB210, or 05103?
Do meteorological datasets in this domain generally consist of daily averages, hourly readings, or 10-minute intervals?

Concept Completion.Question: What are the primary data collection methods used in compiling meteorological datasets for the southeastern Tibetan Plateau?
What challenges are associated with accurately estimating temperature and precipitation gradients in mountainous regions like the southeastern Tibetan Plateau?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to estimate temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients in mountainous regions?
Example.Answer: A data collection method involves using data from multiple meteorological stations situated at different altitudes, such as the 11 meteorological stations on Sejila Mountain. These stations provide temperature and precipitation data used to estimate temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients through regression analysis based on elevation differences.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in collecting and analyzing meteorological data in complex terrain like Sejila Mountain?
Example.Answer: A challenge in collecting and analyzing meteorological data in complex terrain such as Sejila Mountain includes the uneven distribution of meteorological stations, particularly the scarcity of stations on the western slope and at higher altitudes, which can affect the accuracy of temperature lapse rate and precipitation gradient estimations.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the essential attributes of meteorological data collected from automatic weather stations in mountainous regions?
Feature Specification.Answer: temperature, relative humidity, wind speed, vapor pressure, atmospheric pressure, daily cumulative precipitation

Feature Specification.Question: What are the challenges associated with estimating vertical temperature gradients in mountainous areas?
Feature Specification.Answer: influence of multiple factors on vertical temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients, positioning of meteorological stations in valley areas rather than ridges, limited number of high-altitude stations

Feature Specification.Question: What features characterize datasets used to analyze temperature and precipitation vertical gradients in southeastern Tibet?
Feature Specification.Answer: data from multiple meteorological stations, daily temperature and precipitation records, several years of coverage, station altitude

Quantification.Question: What is the average temperature lapse rate observed across the Sejila Mountain stations from 2013 to 2018?
What is the altitude of the meteorological station at Zangdongnan station where basic meteorological data was collected?

Definition.Question: How are vertical temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients estimated using meteorological station data?
Definition.Answer: Vertical temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients are estimated using meteorological station data by conducting regression analysis on the relationship between station elevation and the recorded temperature or precipitation amounts. This involves utilizing data from multiple stations located at varying altitudes to determine how temperature or precipitation changes with elevation, as done with the 11 meteorological stations in the 色季拉山 region.

Definition.Question: What challenges might arise in accurately determining temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients in complex terrains?
Definition.Answer: Challenges in accurately determining temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients in complex terrains include the influence of various factors such as microclimates, topography, and limited station distribution. For instance, in the 色季拉山 area, most meteorological stations are located in valleys rather than ridge tops, and there are fewer stations on the western slope, which could affect the accuracy of the lapse rates and precipitation gradient estimates.

Comparison.Question: How does the data quality in a dataset collected by an automatic weather station compare to that collected by traditional manual observation techniques in terms of completeness and reliability?
Comparison.Answer: The metadata indicates that the dataset collected by the automatic weather station has good original data quality with few missing values, suggesting a high level of completeness and reliability. In contrast, traditional manual observation techniques may be more prone to human error and missing data.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in the challenges faced when estimating temperature lapse rates using data from multiple meteorological stations versus using a single station in mountainous regions?
Comparison.Answer: The challenges include factors affecting temperature lapse rates such as station location; multiple stations might provide a more comprehensive view by capturing variations across different elevations and slopes, whereas a single station might not account for the variability across a large area. Additionally, the scarcity of high-altitude stations can limit the accuracy of estimates from multiple stations.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do datasets from meteorological stations in valley areas differ from those on ridges in terms of their impact on understanding precipitation gradients in mountainous regions?
Comparison.Answer: Datasets from stations in valley areas might reflect more localized climatic conditions and potentially underestimate the influence of elevation on precipitation. In contrast, ridge stations could provide more generalizable data regarding precipitation gradients over larger areas. The placement of most stations in valleys can thus affect the perceived accuracy of the precipitation gradient.

Interpretation.Question: How can the observed temperature and precipitation gradients in mountainous regions be used to infer potential ecological impacts on vegetation distribution along different slopes?
Interpretation.Answer: The observed temperature and precipitation gradients, such as those in the 色季拉山 region, provide insights into slope-specific ecological conditions. These gradients can influence the physiological and ecological characteristics of plant species, potentially affecting their distribution along the slopes. Understanding these gradients helps predict changes in vegetation types and distribution, which is critical for ecological research and conservation efforts.

Interpretation.Question: What data collection methods could be implemented to address the challenge of accurately estimating temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients in high-altitude mountainous areas?
Interpretation.Answer: One effective approach could involve deploying a network of weather stations at various elevations and aspects to capture microclimatic variations. In the 色季拉山 area, using a combination of valley and ridge stations helps counter the challenge of limited high-altitude and western slope data. Regression analysis between station elevation and climatic variables can then be applied to estimate lapse rates and gradients more accurately.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes variations in temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients across different slopes of a mountain range?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Variations in temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients across different slopes of a mountain range can be caused by factors such as slope orientation, altitude, and monsoon influence, which affect how temperature and precipitation change with elevation.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential effects on data accuracy when using automated weather station data for measuring meteorological variables in the mountainous regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of automated weather station data in mountainous regions like the one described can lead to high data accuracy due to frequent measurements (e.g., every 10 minutes), which minimize gaps and provide detailed temporal coverage. However, the challenging terrain and limited number of sites can potentially affect the true representation of vertical gradients for temperature and precipitation.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the integration of multiple datasets from different meteorological stations affect the understanding of vertical temperature and precipitation gradients in mountainous areas?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating datasets from multiple meteorological stations can enhance understanding of vertical temperature and precipitation gradients by providing a comprehensive view across different elevations and slopes. This approach can help identify variations in gradients due to geographical factors, although variability in station positioning (e.g., valley versus ridge) may introduce inconsistencies if not properly accounted for.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications for hydrological modeling in the region when using meteorological data collected from diverse elevations and slopes?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using meteorological data from diverse elevations and slopes can significantly improve hydrological modeling accuracy in the region by offering a nuanced understanding of how climatic variables like temperature and precipitation vary with altitude and aspect. This detailed input can lead to more reliable predictions and assessments of water resources and ecosystem dynamics.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the purpose of collecting meteorological data from diverse altitudes in mountainous regions like the Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to explore the vertical variations in temperature and precipitation, which are essential for understanding the climatic and hydrological dynamics in such regions, and to provide reliable data for climate, hydrology, and glacier research.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to have multiple meteorological stations across different slopes in the Tibetan Plateau for studying climate variations?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Having multiple stations allows for a comprehensive analysis of the vertical lapse rates of temperature and precipitation gradients on different slopes, which helps in understanding the physiological and ecological characteristics of flora and fauna distributions with altitude and supports future hydrological modeling.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended outcomes of estimating temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients from meteorological data in mountain ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to deepen the understanding of how slope direction affects vertical gradients of temperature and precipitation, which further aids in ecological and environmental studies, and provides critical data support for hydrological simulations in the region.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the instrumental techniques and procedures used to collect meteorological data in mountainous regions, particularly regarding the deployment and maintenance of automatic weather stations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedure involves setting up automatic weather stations (AWS) with specific instruments such as HMP155A temperature and humidity probes, TB4 rain gauges, PTB210 atmospheric pressure sensors, and 05103 wind speed sensors. These instruments are installed at a height of 2 meters above the ground, which is grassland in the specified location, to record meteorological data like temperature, humidity, wind speed, vapor pressure, and atmospheric pressure at 10-minute intervals.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can meteorological data be processed to estimate temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients in complex terrain such as the southeastern Tibetan Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data is processed by collecting temperature and precipitation records from multiple meteorological stations at various elevations. Regression analysis is then performed using the elevation of each station to estimate temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients. This approach helps in understanding the vertical variation of temperature and precipitation in relation to altitude.

Enablement.Question: What data collection methods have enabled the accurate recording of meteorological data such as temperature and humidity in high-altitude grassland environments?
Enablement.Answer: The use of automated weather stations (AWS) equipped with specific sensors, such as the HMP155A temperature and humidity probe, TB4 rain gauge, PTB210 barometric pressure sensor, and 05103 wind speed sensor, positioned at a height of 2 meters above the ground, has enabled accurate data collection in these environments.

Enablement.Question: How do specific challenges in terrain, such as limited high-altitude stations, influence the accuracy of temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients in mountainous regions?
Enablement.Answer: The limited number of high-altitude stations and the placement of most stations in valley areas can affect the accuracy of the temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients obtained, as these factors are influenced by various environmental elements, including the station's elevation and geographical positioning.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or resources contributed to the availability and continuity of meteorological datasets from the Tibetan Plateau region for climate and hydrological research?
Enablement.Answer: The establishment of meteorological stations across different elevations and aspects, such as the stations provided by the Tibet Autonomous Region Meteorological Bureau, and the ongoing updates from research stations like the Southeast Tibet Station, ensure the availability and continuity of datasets for climate and hydrological research.

Expectation.Question: Why might data collected from meteorological stations located in valleys differ in expected accuracy compared to stations located on ridges or high-altitude areas?
Expectation.Answer: Due to factors affecting temperature lapse rate and precipitation gradient, most meteorological stations, except for a few located on ridges, are situated in valleys, which could impact the accuracy of the temperature lapse rate and precipitation gradient measurements.

Expectation.Question: What potential challenges could arise from using data from a limited number of high-altitude meteorological stations to estimate temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges may arise because there are fewer high-altitude stations on the western slope, which could affect the ability to obtain a more accurate temperature lapse rate and precipitation gradient.

Expectation.Question: Why might the temperature lapse rate vary year-to-year in the same geographical area, and how can this variation be accounted for in datasets?
Expectation.Answer: The yearly variation in the temperature lapse rate, with the lowest value observed in some years and the highest in others, suggests that annual climatic changes affect the rate, which needs to be accounted for in datasets by using long-term average values for more reliable estimates.

Judgmental.Question: What are the implications of the observed temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients for future research on ecological and hydrological processes in mountainous regions?
Judgmental.Answer: The observed temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients provide critical insights into the ecological and hydrological processes, such as plant distribution and water cycle dynamics. These findings could guide future research to refine ecological models and improve hydrological simulations, considering the variability in temperature and precipitation with altitude.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of the challenges faced in collecting accurate meteorological data across diverse terrains in the Tibetan Plateau.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges in collecting meteorological data in diverse terrains like the Tibetan Plateau include the limited number of high-altitude stations, which can skew data, and the geographical distribution of these stations, which may not fully represent the vertical gradients of temperature and precipitation due to factors like slope orientation and valley placement.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the potential datasets available that could help in studying the vertical gradients of temperature and precipitation in mountainous areas.
Assertion.Answer: Potential datasets for studying vertical gradients in mountainous areas include those from multiple meteorological stations like those in the Tibetan Plateau, which provide data on temperature, humidity, wind speed, vapor pressure, and atmospheric pressure. These datasets include daily averages and cumulative values, which can be used to understand patterns and gradients across different elevations.

Request/Directive.Question: Please outline potential strategies for expanding and refining datasets related to meteorological observations in complex terrains like mountain regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential strategies for expanding and refining datasets in complex terrains such as mountain regions could include increasing the number of observation sites to cover more varied topographies, using higher frequency data collection intervals to capture short-term weather variations, integrating remote sensing data to complement ground-based observations, and employing statistical models to interpolate data for areas between stations. Additionally, collaboration with local meteorological agencies to access and combine datasets from multiple sources could enhance spatial and temporal coverage.

Request/Directive.Question: Please investigate how the vertical gradients of temperature and precipitation are estimated in mountain regions and the factors that might influence these estimations.
Request/Directive.Answer: The vertical gradients of temperature and precipitation in mountain regions are estimated by analyzing the relationship between elevation and these meteorological variables across multiple observation sites. Regression analysis is commonly used to determine the rate of change in temperature (e.g., lapse rates) and precipitation with altitude. Factors influencing these estimations include the geographical distribution of observation sites, with potential biases introduced by uneven site distribution, local topography such as valleys and ridges, and the number of high-altitude observation points. Seasonal variations, such as monsoon and non-monsoon periods, also play a significant role in influencing precipitation gradients.
